The Inter-Fraternity Board
this morning considered a motion that, if voted on and passed,
would reverse its decision of last
year to bar Zeta Beta Tau from
IFB membership.
At last Friday's IFB meeting
in Levering Hall, Board President
Steve Broening asked the fraternity representatives to bring the
question of ZBT admittance back
to their fraternities so that it
could "perhaps be decided" this
week.
Following Broening's statement, discussion arose as to
whether ZBT desired admittance
to the board or had made application for it. It was reported
that ZBT intended to apply later
in the year "when conditions are
favorable," but Broening said: "I
feel ZBT is at present a stable
fraternity, and if they can prove
themselves on the board, they
should be admitted."
No strong objections • were
voiced. Delta Phi representativeDick Ridenour spoke in favor of

"The Penal Education Program of the Johns Hopkins University YMCA can now be called a success," Dr.
Chester Wickwire, executive secretary of the Levering
Hall organization announced today:
For the last month the YMCA has been sending
Hopkins students to the Maryland State Penitentiary •
where they have been working in conjunction with the
inmate instructor there, teaching prisoners courses ranging from reading to college level French.
"The objectives of the program are simple ones,"
Mac Johnson, one of the participating students noted,
"we are trying to rehabilitate the inmates by broadening
their knowledge and by helping them develop useful and
constructive skills."

Inert, Inept, In TroubIe
There is an undercurrent of thought, justified by long
experience, within the Hopkins administration which sees
the Hopkins man as regressing from a former state of
sophistication and gentlemanliness toward a condition of
freedom unbridled by responsibility where the student
government is unwilling to take the necessary, albeit
unpopular, steps to preserve the code, of the gentleman.
This indictment of the individual students does not
apply to the large majority. However, the havoc which
a few can cause was vividly portraited in the aftermath
of the Cotillion Ball. Their action+ were the straw that
broke the camel's back and gave rise to the plea that the
gymnasium be closed to future student social affairs unless adequate provision is made to insure reasonable respect for the property. The furor subsided somewhat
with the Pajama Ball, which didn't draw a turnout
comparable in size. But the stillness is of a volcanic
nature, ready to erupt with any future disturbance.
The administration will not stand idle again. Either
the student government will act to alleviate a future
situation or will have its prerogatives usurped.
There seems a need for some organization to exercise executive and judicial discretion not to insure restrictions on merriment within a rigid framework, but
rather to arrest the tendency to needless destruction and
general social riot.
The Student Council would be the natural organ to
handle this function. Yet, it has been reluctant to enforce or restrict in the past and has degenerated to a
mere debating society. Its lack of prestige and need for
popularity have caused capable students to look elsewhere
to satisfy their leadership instincts.

The Forgotten Man Ile was a controversial man. Fo; seventy-eight
years he stubbornly kept faith with himself, this nearly
neckless man with the overly wide mouth and the dark
eyes. Son of a wealthy and thrifty Maryland family imbued with Quakerism, he felt pressing obligations to
maintain his ancestors' good reputation and financial
status.
A successful merchant at an early age, possessor of
eight million dollars at his death; a bachelor devoted to
his relatives and their progeny; shrewd and commonsensical; opponent of slavery and whiskey, he gave freely
of his time, abilities and fortunes to his city and state,
never seeking to dominate but merely to serve.
Omitted in yearbooks and mentioned only slightly
in the official history of this university, he is commemorated by a statue which faces Charles and- 33rd Streets,
its marble pillar and base bearing paint scars of intercollegiate rivalries. Undergraduates have carved their
initials into his oxidized bronze forehead; they have
polished and rouged the bosom of the female figure of
Wisdom which sits at his feet.
Leaves stagnate in brown water in the fountainpool at the pillar's foundations.
The neglected and abused statue is a symbol of the
university's forgotten man, Johns Hopkins.'

they were snatched up, planted, limed, and watered, and today
they support a hammock in Cut and Shoot, Vermont.

Famous Poets Read Own Work,
Lecture To Crowds In Shriver
The greatest literary event
that Baltimore has seen in recent years took place at the Hopkins during the past week-anda-half. Covering a variety of
poetic natures and types, from
the cold and dissecting critic to
the witty, urbane and feeling
man, the Poetry Festival must
be considered a great success
from both an artistic and a popular point of view.
There were two outstanding
enjoyable days during the Festival and, strangely enough, both
were provided by poets instead
of critics. Robert Frost, who read
and spun some of his characteristic home-philosophy on Sunday afternoon, was both entertaining, "educational" and plain
funny. Archibald MacLeish was
witty, sophisticated and profoundly fascinating.
The Poet Alone
MacLeish's theme might be
called "aloneness." He asserted
that the man alone is the poetical man and the poet's man. He
drew his image from the Soviet
writer Boris Pasternak who is
"a symbol of man .
alone in
the world:" It is the man who
dares to be alone that MacLeish
admires; the poet, like Pasternak, is alone in "the struggle of
the single spirit against the faceless mob."
Prof. MacLeish intimated in

Scalions

RUN INN
Coffee Shop

Poet-critic Yvor Winters delivered a leeture last Friday on
"Poetic Styles, Old and New."
Prof. Winters discussed poems of
John Donne, evinced a dislike
for Sir Philip Sidney and
pointed out weaknesses in that
previous untouchable of English
literature, Mr. William Shakespeare.
Prof. Winters liked Ben Johnson and, in modern poetry, Wallace Stevens, though he doesn't
always agree with Stevens' ideas.
E. E. Cummings
Mr. Edward Estlin Cummings
preceded Robert Frost on Sunday afternoon. He, in contrast to
Mr. Frost, seemed a little nervous
and read his ,poems slowly and

reflectingly. The greatest stir was
ROBERT FROST
his comments that he has mellowed since he was "a very old
man very young." The poems he
read were profound without being very obscure and reflected a
man who feels very keenly the
world in which he lives.
Responsive Audience
Robert Frost spoke before an
auditorium of filled seats, occupied wall space, and loudspeakered rooms.
He read poems which everyone
knew and, he knew, expected
to hear. He said plainly that he
intended to sneak in a few less
well-known poems and did. The
audience was just as responsive
and laughed heartily at the
poet's wiseaacks and his often
subtle sarcasms.

The Johns Hopkins varsity
football team will entertain a
surprising Dickinson eleven at

jelling and has defeated the last
three opponents to even their

only six of them backs. There is
a chance that blocking back Al
Freeland will return, along with
Russ sMartenson and Rod Simonsen, Who played briefly last week.
Garcia Passes
Little Oz Garcia, the running
sensa.tion in the early part of
the season, showed his versatility
by passing the Blue Jays to a
24-0 victory at Swarthmore last
Saturday.
Garcia completed ten of his
16 attempted passes for a total
of 223 yards. The favorite target
of the wingback was end Bob
Brannan, who pulled in five
passes for 78 yards and two
Hopkins touchdowns. Both of his
touchdowns came in the first
quarter as the Jays jumped out
in front 12-0. Both tries for the
bonus points were by the aerial
route but were unsuccessful.

Season Ends Today
For Frosh Eleven
By PAUL MUSICANT
The Gettysburg freshmen play
host to the Johns Hopkins freshman football team in the Jays'
season finale today.
Although the Bullets usually
field a powerful team, Hopkins
Coach Bob Scott feels that with
the right approach, in particular
good defensive play, the Jays can
pull an upset.
Thus far G-Burg sports a 1-2
record with a win over Shippensberg State and losses to Bucknell
and Bullis Prep.
Rolling to their third straight
victory of the season, the Hopkins frosh, though outweight 1520 lbs. per man, humbled Baltimore Junior College, 20-0, last
Friday at Homewood.
Top Performances
Outstanding in the team performance were halfback Henry
Jerry
ends
and
Ciccarone
Schmidt and Terry Weltman.
Ciccarone threw a long pass
for one T-D, while scoring another himself. Schmidt was the
middle man on a pass lateral
play which resulted in a Hopkins
6-pointers scoring himself on a
pass from quaterback Bill Powell.
Right end Weltman scored eight
points on a pass-run play and an
extra point reception.
A scoreless first quarter found
the Jays penetrating to the
B.J.C. thirty-eight on fine running by Ciccarone, but the Red
and White stiffened, forcing
Hopkins to punt. The Jays kept
their opponents deep in B.J.C.
territory for the entire period.
In the second stanza, the Blue
took possession on their own 49
after a B.J.C. punt. Ciccarone
took a handoff and threw . per-

feet pass into the outstretched
arms of Welmam on the Collegians 25, and the fleet end
sprinted all the way for a 51 yard
score. The attempt for the bonus
two points failed.
Jays Lead Increased
On the first play following the
kickoff, Hopkins recovered a
B.J.C. fumble on the latter's 35.
After two unsuccessful plays,
Ciccarone whipped a pass downfield to end Schmidt who capped
it on the 20. About to be tackled,
he lateralled to Ciccarone, who
streaked in for the T.D. Powell's
sneak for the extra points failed,
and the half ended with Hopkins
ahead 12-0.
Soon after the second half began. Powell intercepted a B.J.C.
pass on the Hopkins 38 and
streaked 45 yard to the Collegians' 17. Advancing to the 2,
Powell, flipped a quick pop pass
to Schmidt for the T-D. A
similar pass to Weltman scored
two more for the Jays, bringing
the final margin to 20-0.
The strong Hopkins line consistently kept Junior College
passers in trouble and kept the
B.J.C. attack at a standstill.
Though not scoring, halfback
Bill Flannery was an outstanding
rusher, consistently picking up
needed yardage.
out
singled
Scott
Coach
tackles John Doud and Dick
Becker, guards Dale Steiger and
Dave Hoover and Center Pat
Boyer for their outstanding defensive play against a heavier
B.J.C. line.

Capacitors which provide for electrical, rather than mechanical
tuning of circuits, are being produced by Hughes Products, the
commercial activity of Hughes.

Information resulting from Hughes study in the fields of
air-to-air and ballistic guided missiles is presently paying
dividends into the fund ofspace knowledge.
Hughes engineers have developed space hardware using
high-reliability wire wrapping to replace soldered connections and miniaturized "cordwood" circuit modules to allow high component density.
The advanced nature of Hughes electronic systems—in
the air, on the ground, and for industry—provides an ideal
growth environment for the graduating or experienced
engineer interested in building rewarding, long-range professional stature.

Systems in the .Air

The march ofelectronicsinto the Space Age is being quickened
as a result of Hughes work in airborne electronics systems.
One such development is the Hughes Electronic Armament System, which pilots high-speed jet interceptors to
enemy targets, launching Hughes air-to-air guided missiles,
and flies the plane home.Even more sophisticated Elthronic
Armament Systems completely outstrip those presently released for publication.
Working on space satellites, Hughes engineers are active
in the preliminary design of guidance and control systems,
communication and telemetry systems,sensing devices using
infrared, optical and radar techniques.

Data Processors, which monitor hundreds of aircraft and store the
information for high-speed assignment of defense weapons,
comprise one part of an advanced Hughes ground defense system.

scheduled
this past week by the
German department for its elementary
and
intermediate
eAcinrses, Dr. William McClain,

Called the uniform exams the
,best possible way to get an obJective picture of all students
taking these courses."
, on Tuesday, November 11, all

their Midterm; on Thursday, No!ember 13, all students enrolled

Of his regular section meetMany called the 4:30 time

ale Part of the Department.
ti_tut Dr. McClain explained

"The Penal Education Program of the Johns Hopkins University YMCA can now be called a success," Dr.
Chester Wickwire, executive secretary of the Levering
Hall organization announced today:
For the last month the YMCA has been sending
Hopkins students to the Maryland State Penitentiary •
where they have been working in conjunction with the
inmate instructor there, teaching prisoners courses ranging from reading to college level French.
"The objectives of the program are simple ones,"
Mac Johnson, one of the participating students noted,
"we are trying to rehabilitate the inmates by broadening
their knowledge and by helping them develop useful and
constructive skills."

diseases, boys' work, and elderly people.

Inert, Inept, In TroubIe
There is an undercurrent of thought, justified by long
experience, within the Hopkins administration which sees
the Hopkins man as regressing from a former state of
sophistication and gentlemanliness toward a condition of
freedom unbridled by responsibility where the student
government is unwilling to take the necessary, albeit
unpopular, steps to preserve the code, of the gentleman.
This indictment of the individual students does not
apply to the large majority. However, the havoc which
a few can cause was vividly portraited in the aftermath
of the Cotillion Ball. Their action+ were the straw that
broke the camel's back and gave rise to the plea that the
gymnasium be closed to future student social affairs unless adequate provision is made to insure reasonable respect for the property. The furor subsided somewhat
with the Pajama Ball, which didn't draw a turnout
comparable in size. But the stillness is of a volcanic
nature, ready to erupt with any future disturbance.
The administration will not stand idle again. Either
the student government will act to alleviate a future
situation or will have its prerogatives usurped.
There seems a need for some organization to exercise executive and judicial discretion not to insure restrictions on merriment within a rigid framework, but
rather to arrest the tendency to needless destruction and
general social riot.
The Student Council would be the natural organ to
handle this function. Yet, it has been reluctant to enforce or restrict in the past and has degenerated to a
mere debating society. Its lack of prestige and need for
popularity have caused capable students to look elsewhere
to satisfy their leadership instincts.

The Forgotten Man Ile was a controversial man. Fo; seventy-eight
years he stubbornly kept faith with himself, this nearly
neckless man with the overly wide mouth and the dark
eyes. Son of a wealthy and thrifty Maryland family imbued with Quakerism, he felt pressing obligations to
maintain his ancestors' good reputation and financial
status.
A successful merchant at an early age, possessor of
eight million dollars at his death; a bachelor devoted to
his relatives and their progeny; shrewd and commonsensical; opponent of slavery and whiskey, he gave freely
of his time, abilities and fortunes to his city and state,
never seeking to dominate but merely to serve.
Omitted in yearbooks and mentioned only slightly
in the official history of this university, he is commemorated by a statue which faces Charles and- 33rd Streets,
its marble pillar and base bearing paint scars of intercollegiate rivalries. Undergraduates have carved their
initials into his oxidized bronze forehead; they have
polished and rouged the bosom of the female figure of
Wisdom which sits at his feet.
Leaves stagnate in brown water in the fountainpool at the pillar's foundations.
The neglected and abused statue is a symbol of the
university's forgotten man, Johns Hopkins.'

Famous Poets Read Own Work,
Lecture To Crowds In Shriver
The greatest literary event
that Baltimore has seen in recent years took place at the Hopkins during the past week-anda-half. Covering a variety of
poetic natures and types, from
the cold and dissecting critic to
the witty, urbane and feeling
man, the Poetry Festival must
be considered a great success
from both an artistic and a popular point of view.
There were two outstanding
enjoyable days during the Festival and, strangely enough, both
were provided by poets instead
of critics. Robert Frost, who read
and spun some of his characteristic home-philosophy on Sunday afternoon, was both entertaining, "educational" and plain
funny. Archibald MacLeish was
witty, sophisticated and profoundly fascinating.
The Poet Alone
MacLeish's theme might be
called "aloneness." He asserted
that the man alone is the poetical man and the poet's man. He
drew his image from the Soviet
writer Boris Pasternak who is
"a symbol of man .
alone in
the world:" It is the man who
dares to be alone that MacLeish
admires; the poet, like Pasternak, is alone in "the struggle of
the single spirit against the faceless mob."

Poet-critic Yvor Winters delivered a leeture last Friday on
"Poetic Styles, Old and New."
Prof. Winters discussed poems of
John Donne, evinced a dislike
for Sir Philip Sidney and
pointed out weaknesses in that
previous untouchable of English
literature, Mr. William Shakespeare.
Prof. Winters liked Ben Johnson and, in modern poetry, Wallace Stevens, though he doesn't
always agree with Stevens' ideas.
E. E. Cummings
Mr. Edward Estlin Cummings
preceded Robert Frost on Sunday afternoon. He, in contrast to
Mr. Frost, seemed a little nervous
and read his ,poems slowly and

reflectingly. The greatest stir was
ROBERT FROST
his comments that he has mellowed since he was "a very old
man very young." The poems he
read were profound without being very obscure and reflected a
man who feels very keenly the
world in which he lives.
Responsive Audience
Robert Frost spoke before an
auditorium of filled seats, occupied wall space, and loudspeakered rooms.
He read poems which everyone
knew and, he knew, expected
to hear. He said plainly that he
intended to sneak in a few less
well-known poems and did. The
audience was just as responsive
and laughed heartily at the
poet's wiseaacks and his often
subtle sarcasms.

The Johns Hopkins varsity
football team will entertain a
surprising Dickinson eleven at
Homewood tomorrow.
After dropping their first three
games, Dickinson finally started
jelling and has defeated the last
three opponents to even their
record. Last year at Dickinson
the game ended in a 13-13 deadlock.
Hopkins will enter the game
well undermanned due to injuries. The squad consists now of
only 26 physically able players,
only six of them backs. There is
a chance that blocking back Al
Freeland will return, along with
Russ sMartenson and Rod Simonsen, Who played briefly last week.
Garcia Passes
Little Oz Garcia, the running
sensa.tion in the early part of
the season, showed his versatility
by passing the Blue Jays to a
24-0 victory at Swarthmore last
Saturday.
Garcia completed ten of his
16 attempted passes for a total
of 223 yards. The favorite target
of the wingback was end Bob
Brannan, who pulled in five
passes for 78 yards and two
Hopkins touchdowns. Both of his
touchdowns came in the first
quarter as the Jays jumped out
in front 12-0. Both tries for the
bonus points were by the aerial
route but were unsuccessful.

once, and that was late in the
third quarter, the only period in
which the Jays didn't score. The
hosts advanced to the Hopkins
one, where they found the Jay
line impenetrable and lost the
ball on downs.
In the fourth period fullback
Rod Simonsen, who injured his
knee in a pre-season scrimmage

Season Ends Today
For Frosh Eleven
By PAUL MUSICANT
The Gettysburg freshmen play
host to the Johns Hopkins freshman football team in the Jays'
season finale today.
Although the Bullets usually
field a powerful team, Hopkins
Coach Bob Scott feels that with
the right approach, in particular
good defensive play, the Jays can
pull an upset.
Thus far G-Burg sports a 1-2
record with a win over Shippensberg State and losses to Bucknell
and Bullis Prep.
Rolling to their third straight
victory of the season, the Hopkins frosh, though outweight 1520 lbs. per man, humbled Baltimore Junior College, 20-0, last
Friday at Homewood.
Top Performances
Outstanding in the team performance were halfback Henry
Jerry
ends
and
Ciccarone
Schmidt and Terry Weltman.
Ciccarone threw a long pass
for one T-D, while scoring another himself. Schmidt was the
middle man on a pass lateral
play which resulted in a Hopkins
6-pointers scoring himself on a
pass from quaterback Bill Powell.
Right end Weltman scored eight
points on a pass-run play and an
extra point reception.
A scoreless first quarter found
the Jays penetrating to the
B.J.C. thirty-eight on fine running by Ciccarone, but the Red
and White stiffened, forcing
Hopkins to punt. The Jays kept
their opponents deep in B.J.C.
territory for the entire period.
In the second stanza, the Blue
took possession on their own 49
after a B.J.C. punt. Ciccarone
took a handoff and threw . per-

feet pass into the outstretched
arms of Welmam on the Collegians 25, and the fleet end
sprinted all the way for a 51 yard
score. The attempt for the bonus
two points failed.
Jays Lead Increased
On the first play following the
kickoff, Hopkins recovered a
B.J.C. fumble on the latter's 35.
After two unsuccessful plays,
Ciccarone whipped a pass downfield to end Schmidt who capped
it on the 20. About to be tackled,
he lateralled to Ciccarone, who
streaked in for the T.D. Powell's
sneak for the extra points failed,
and the half ended with Hopkins
ahead 12-0.
Soon after the second half began. Powell intercepted a B.J.C.
pass on the Hopkins 38 and
streaked 45 yard to the Collegians' 17. Advancing to the 2,
Powell, flipped a quick pop pass
to Schmidt for the T-D. A
similar pass to Weltman scored
two more for the Jays, bringing
the final margin to 20-0.
The strong Hopkins line consistently kept Junior College
passers in trouble and kept the
B.J.C. attack at a standstill.
Though not scoring, halfback
Bill Flannery was an outstanding
rusher, consistently picking up
needed yardage.
out
singled
Scott
Coach
tackles John Doud and Dick
Becker, guards Dale Steiger and
Dave Hoover and Center Pat
Boyer for their outstanding defensive play against a heavier
B.J.C. line.

The Freshmen booters completed an undefeated season as
they edged a mixed Freshmen
and varsity group of Towson
Staters by a score of 3-2 at the
latter's field on November 11.
Sal Cumo, Jay scoring ace, again
led the team by hitting for three
goals.
"This game was a great accoach.
complishment," stated
Hartman,"for we played without
the services of Bill Faust, the
leader of our defensive unit."
Faust had played every game up
to this tilt, but was forced out of
the lineup when he contracted

Capacitors which provide for electrical, rather than mechanical
tuning of circuits, are being produced by Hughes Products, the
commercial activity of Hughes.

Information resulting from Hughes study in the fields of
air-to-air and ballistic guided missiles is presently paying
dividends into the fund ofspace knowledge.
Hughes engineers have developed space hardware using
high-reliability wire wrapping to replace soldered connections and miniaturized "cordwood" circuit modules to allow high component density.
The advanced nature of Hughes electronic systems—in
the air, on the ground, and for industry—provides an ideal
growth environment for the graduating or experienced
engineer interested in building rewarding, long-range professional stature.

Systems in the .Air

The march ofelectronicsinto the Space Age is being quickened
as a result of Hughes work in airborne electronics systems.
One such development is the Hughes Electronic Armament System, which pilots high-speed jet interceptors to
enemy targets, launching Hughes air-to-air guided missiles,
and flies the plane home.Even more sophisticated Elthronic
Armament Systems completely outstrip those presently released for publication.
Working on space satellites, Hughes engineers are active
in the preliminary design of guidance and control systems,
communication and telemetry systems,sensing devices using
infrared, optical and radar techniques.

Data Processors, which monitor hundreds of aircraft and store the
information for high-speed assignment of defense weapons,
comprise one part of an advanced Hughes ground defense system.
